clusters.title: 300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US to be released, says Seoul
clusters.neutral_headline: South Korea and US Reach Agreement on Hyundai Plant Detainees

items.title: 300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US to be released, says Seoul
items.standfirst: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...

This is the latest in a long line of workplace raids conducted as part of the Trump administration’s mass deportation…

items.content: South Korean workers detained in an immigration raid in the US state of Georgia are to be released and flown home.

items.title: South Korea says it has reached a deal with the US for the release of workers in a Georgia plant

items.content: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung ordered all out efforts to respond to the arrests of its citizens in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia.

items.title: Seoul promises to help hundreds of Korean workers arrested in US in Ice raid
items.standfirst: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. Continue reading...
items.content: Total of 475 detained in Georgia at construction site of factory to make batteries for Hyundai and Kia carsSouth Korea’s president, Lee Jae Myung, has ordered “all-out efforts” to respond to the arrest of hundreds of its citizens by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) during a raid at a factory being built in Georgia to manufacture car batteries.Cho Hyun, the foreign minister, said the government had set up a taskforce following the arrest of 300 South Korean nationals. ai_summary: South Korea and the US reached an agreement regarding detained Hyundai plant workers.
Over 300 South Korean workers were detained during a US immigration raid in Georgia.
The South Korean government announced the workers would be released and flown home.
The raid occurred at a Hyundai-LG battery plant in Ellabell, Georgia.
The detentions strained diplomatic and economic relations between the two nations.

clusters.title: Zelensky condemns 'ruthless attack' after Russia hits main government building in Kyiv
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia Attacks Kyiv, Damaging Government Building

items.title: Zelensky condemns 'ruthless attack' after Russia hits main government building in Kyiv
items.standfirst: It is the first time a Kyiv government building - in the heavily protected city centre - has been hit since Russia launched its full-scale invasion.
items.content: It is the first time a Kyiv government building - in the heavily protected city centre - has been hit since Russia launched its full-scale invasion.

items.title: Largest Russian air attack of war sets fire to Ukrainian cabinet building
items.standfirst: Officials say three people including mother and baby killed in strikes that also hit key government building for first timeRussia has launched its largest ever air attack on Ukraine, hitting a key government building in Kyiv for the first time and killing at least three people, including a mother and her baby, and drawing widespread condemnation, including a fresh threat of further US sanctions.The bombardment of the capital with a large number of drones and missiles injured at least 18 people and set scores of buildings on fire. Explosions were also reported in the cities of Odesa, Kharkiv, Dnipro, Zaporizhzhia and Kryvyi Rih. Authorities triggered a countrywide air-raid warning at 6.06am local time and later accused Russia of deliberately striking civilian targets. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials say three people including mother and baby killed in strikes that also hit key government building for first timeRussia has launched its largest ever air attack on Ukraine, hitting a key government building in Kyiv for the first time and killing at least three people, including a mother and her baby, and drawing widespread condemnation, including a fresh threat of further US sanctions.The bombardment of the capital with a large number of drones and missiles injured at least 18 people and set scores of buildings on fire. Explosions were also reported in the cities of Odesa, Kharkiv, Dnipro, Zaporizhzhia and Kryvyi Rih. Authorities triggered a countrywide air-raid warning at 6.06am local time and later accused Russia of deliberately striking civilian targets. Continue reading...

items.title: Ukraine government building damaged in large Russia aerial attack
items.standfirst: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.
items.content: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.

items.title: Russia launches record mass drone attack on Ukraine

items.content: Moscow’s forces fire 805 drones in one night, striking government building in Kyiv

items.title: Russia hits Ukraine with more that 800 drones and decoy drones in biggest-ever aerial barrage
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.

items.title: Russia Strikes Ukraine Government Building in Largest Drone Attack Yet | WSJ News

items.content: A young mother and her child were killed in Kyiv, Ukraine, during the largest aerial bombardment by Russia since the war began.

items.title: Russia damages Kyiv government building in the largest aerial attack since war began

items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building.

items.title: Russia launches largest attack of war, strikes Ukraine government building

Drones also hit residential buildings in Kyiv; Ukraine’s president called the attack “vile.” With peace efforts stalled, the war…

Drones also hit residential buildings in Kyiv; Ukraine’s president called the attack “vile.” With peace efforts stalled, the war…

items.title: Record Russian drone attack pounds Ukraine, damaging government building
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, killing at least two people and leaving smoke rising from the roof of a key government building. Story by Shirli Sitbon.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, killing at least two people and leaving smoke rising from the roof of a key government building. Story by Shirli Sitbon.

items.title: Watch: BBC at the scene of Ukrainian government building strike
items.standfirst: One of Kyiv's main government buildings was hit in overnight missile and drone strikes by Russia.
items.content: One of Kyiv's main government buildings was hit in overnight missile and drone strikes by Russia.

items.title: Russia conducts massive air attack on Kyiv, other Ukrainian regions
items.standfirst: Russia hit Kyiv and other parts of Ukraine with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since its full-scale invasion, killing at least four people and setting the seat of the Ukrainian government in the capital ablaze. France 24's Gulliver Cragg reports from Kyiv.
items.content: Russia hit Kyiv and other parts of Ukraine with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since its full-scale invasion, killing at least four people and setting the seat of the Ukrainian government in the capital ablaze. France 24's Gulliver Cragg reports from Kyiv.

items.title: Russia assaults Ukraine with over 800 drones and decoys, the largest such attack in the war
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began.(Image credit: Evgeniy Maloletka)

items.title: Ukrainian government building damaged in massive Russian air attack
items.standfirst: Russia fired its largest aerial attack on Ukraine since the war began, setting the main government building in central Kyiv ablaze and damaging the structure before the fire was put out, officials said Sunday. At least four people, including an infant, were killed and dozens wounded across the country as Russia launched more than 800 drones and 13 missiles in the attacks, Ukraine’s air force added.
items.content: Russia fired its largest aerial attack on Ukraine since the war began, setting the main government building in central Kyiv ablaze and damaging the structure before the fire was put out, officials said Sunday. At least four people, including an infant, were killed and dozens wounded across the country as Russia launched more than 800 drones and 13 missiles in the attacks, Ukraine’s air force added.

ai_summary: Russia launched its largest air attack on Ukraine, hitting a Kyiv government building.
The attack killed at least three people, including a mother and her baby.
Explosions were reported in multiple Ukrainian cities, including Odesa and Kharkiv.
Ukraine's air force reported the attack involved over 800 drones and decoys.
The attack drew widespread condemnation and threats of further US sanctions.

clusters.title: Pope Leo XIV canonizes ‘God’s influencer’ Carlo Acutis as the first millennial saint
clusters.neutral_headline: Pope Declares Carlo Acutis the First Millennial Saint

items.title: Pope Leo XIV canonizes ‘God’s influencer’ Carlo Acutis as the first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV declared a 15-year-old computer whiz the Catholic Church’s first millennial saint Sunday, giving the next generation of Catholics a relatable role model who used technology to spread the faith and earn the nickname “God’s influencer.”
items.content: Pope Leo XIV declared a 15-year-old computer whiz the Catholic Church’s first millennial saint Sunday, giving the next generation of Catholics a relatable role model who used technology to spread the faith and earn the nickname “God’s influencer.”

items.title: Thousands flock to Vatican as teenager made first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.
items.content: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.

items.title: Carlo Acutis, ‘God’s influencer’ who died age 15, declared a saint by Pope Leo
items.standfirst: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...
items.content: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...

items.title: Pope declares 'God's influencer' first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.
items.content: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.

items.title: Pope Leo declares teen millennial , known as ‘God’s influencer’, a saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, a digital pioneer, used his computer skills to spread Catholic teaching globally.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, a digital pioneer, used his computer skills to spread Catholic teaching globally.

items.title: Pope Leo declares Italian teen computer whiz a saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.

items.title: Pope Leo canonizes 'God's influencer,' the Catholic Church's first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St.

items.title: Teen gamer who 'performed miracles' becomes first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Before his death at 15, Carlo Acutis was known for his love of technology and had created a website to document miracles.
items.content: Before his death at 15, Carlo Acutis was known for his love of technology and had created a website to document miracles.

items.title: A teen nicknamed 'God's influencer' has become the first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, who died of leukemia at 15 in 2006, is known in the Catholic Church as "God's influencer" for harnessing technology to spread the word about miracles.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, who died of leukemia at 15 in 2006, is known in the Catholic Church as "God's influencer" for harnessing technology to spread the word about miracles.(Image credit: Valerio Muscella for NPR)

items.title: Teen known as 'God's influencer' to become the first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Known as 'God's influencer' Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint at a solemn canonization Mass held by Pope Leo XIV.
items.content: Known as 'God's influencer' Carlo Acutis will become the first millennial saint at a solemn canonization Mass held by Pope Leo XIV.

ai_summary: Pope Leo XIV canonized Carlo Acutis, the first millennial saint.
Acutis was a 15-year-old computer whiz who died of leukemia.
He used technology to spread Catholic teaching and earned the nickname "God's influencer."
Thousands gathered at the Vatican for the canonization ceremony.
Acutis is credited with two miracles, leading to his sainthood.

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Ishiba Resigns, Most Likely To Be Replaced With Hard-Line Conservative
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Ishiba Resigns, Most Likely To Be Replaced With Hard-Line Conservative For much of the past two months, ever since the historic loss of Japan's LDP in July's parliamentary elections, we have mocked the highly unpopular Japanese PM Shigeru Ishiba, who was clinging to the…
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Ishiba Resigns, Most Likely To Be Replaced With Hard-Line Conservative For much of the past two months, ever since the historic loss of Japan's LDP in July's parliamentary elections, we have mocked the highly unpopular Japanese PM Shigeru Ishiba, who was clinging to the…

items.title: Japanese prime minister resigns, takes fall for disappointing elections
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigned on Sunday, bowing to internal party pressure after a poor performance in July legislative elections. Ishiba’s abrupt announcement — he was less than a year in the job — comes days after Tokyo finalized a trade deal with Washington setting 15% tariffs…
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigned on Sunday, bowing to internal party pressure after a poor performance in July legislative elections. Ishiba’s abrupt announcement — he was less than a year in the job — comes days after Tokyo finalized a trade deal with Washington setting 15% tariffs…

items.title: Japan’s Prime Minister Ishiba resigns after his party suffered historic defeat in July election
items.standfirst: Ishiba had resisted demands from opponents further to the right within his own party to resign. He argued that he wanted to avoid a political vacuum at a time when Japan faces key domestic and international challenges, including U.S. tariffs, rising prices and growing tensions in the Asia-Pacific.
items.content: Ishiba had resisted demands from opponents further to the right within his own party to resign. He argued that he wanted to avoid a political vacuum at a time when Japan faces key domestic and international challenges, including U.S. tariffs, rising prices and growing tensions in the Asia-Pacific.

items.title: Japan's Shigeru Ishiba resigns after his party suffered a historic defeat in a summer election
items.standfirst: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced Sunday that he will resign, following growing calls from within his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July’s parliamentary election. Story by Catherine Viette.
items.content: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced Sunday that he will resign, following growing calls from within his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July’s parliamentary election. Story by Catherine Viette.

items.title: More uncertainty hits the world’s fourth-largest economy as Japan’s PM to step down after less than a year in power
items.standfirst: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said on Sunday he would step down after less than a year in power, during which he lost his majority in both houses of parliament. The announcement means fresh uncertainty for the world’s fourth-largest economy as it battles rising food prices and deals with…
items.content: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said on Sunday he would step down after less than a year in power, during which he lost his majority in both houses of parliament. The announcement means fresh uncertainty for the world’s fourth-largest economy as it battles rising food prices and deals with…

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigns after election defeats
items.standfirst: The prime minister had struggled to inspire confidence as Japan faced economic headwinds.
items.content: The prime minister had struggled to inspire confidence as Japan faced economic headwinds.

items.title: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba resigns
items.standfirst: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba has resigned after pressure from within his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the potential for a leadership vote against him.
items.content: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba has resigned after pressure from within his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the potential for a leadership vote against him.

items.title: Japan PM Shigeru Ishiba to resign amid fallout from disastrous elections
items.standfirst: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...
items.content: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to resign
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.(Image credit: Philip Fong)

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to step down
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday.
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday.

items.title: Embattled Japanese PM Shigeru Ishiba to resign, media report
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to step down, local media reported on Sunday, as members of his ruling party seek to hold a new leadership race following disastrous upper house elections. James Simms, a freelance journalist based in Tokyo reports on the political crisis.
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to step down, local media reported on Sunday, as members of his ruling party seek to hold a new leadership race following disastrous upper house elections. James Simms, a freelance journalist based in Tokyo reports on the political crisis.

items.title: Japan’s embattled Prime Minister Ishiba resigns after election debacle
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigned on Sunday following calls to take responsibility for his party's historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigned on Sunday following calls to take responsibility for his party's historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.

ai_summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba resigned after a poor election performance.
Ishiba's resignation came after less than a year in office.
His party suffered a historic defeat in July's parliamentary elections.
The resignation creates uncertainty for the world's fourth-largest economy.
Ishiba faced pressure from within his party to take responsibility.

clusters.title: Microsoft says Azure affected after cables cut in the Red Sea

items.title: Microsoft says Azure affected after cables cut in the Red Sea
items.standfirst: Microsoft said Saturday that clients of its Azure cloud platform might experience increased latency after multiple undersea cables were cut in the Red Sea, as reported in Bloomberg. In a status update, the company said traffic going through the Middle East or ending in Asia or Europe had been…
items.content: Microsoft said Saturday that clients of its Azure cloud platform might experience increased latency after multiple undersea cables were cut in the Red Sea, as reported in Bloomberg. In a status update, the company said traffic going through the Middle East or ending in Asia or Europe had been…

items.title: Microsoft cloud services disrupted by Red Sea cable cuts
items.standfirst: Unexplained damage to the cables is causing delays in traffic going through the Middle East, the tech giant says.
items.content: Unexplained damage to the cables is causing delays in traffic going through the Middle East, the tech giant says.

items.title: Internet access in Middle East and Asia disrupted after 'undersea cables cut'
items.standfirst: Internet access in parts of Asia and the Middle East was disrupted after undersea cables were cut, experts have said.
items.content: Internet access in parts of Asia and the Middle East was disrupted after undersea cables were cut, experts have said.

items.title: Undersea cables cut in the Red Sea, disrupting internet access in Asia and the Mideast
items.standfirst: Undersea cable cuts in the Red Sea disrupted internet access in parts of Asia and the Middle East, experts said Sunday, though it wasn’t immediately clear what caused the incident.
items.content: Undersea cable cuts in the Red Sea disrupted internet access in parts of Asia and the Middle East, experts said Sunday, though it wasn’t immediately clear what caused the incident.

items.title: Internet disruptions in Middle East and South Asia after Red Sea cable cuts
items.standfirst: Microsoft warns customers of 'increased latency' in connectivity and says efforts are under way to resolve the issue.
items.content: Microsoft warns customers of 'increased latency' in connectivity and says efforts are under way to resolve the issue.

items.title: Microsoft Says Azure Service Fine After Red Sea Cables Cut
items.standfirst: Microsoft Corp. said Saturday it’s no longer detecting issues with its Azure cloud platform after multiple international cables in the Red Sea were cut.
items.content: Microsoft Corp. said Saturday it’s no longer detecting issues with its Azure cloud platform after multiple international cables in the Red Sea were cut.

ai_summary: Microsoft reported potential latency issues for Azure cloud platform users.
Multiple undersea cables were cut in the Red Sea.
Traffic through the Middle East, Asia, and Europe may be affected.
The company is working to resolve the issue.
Internet access in parts of Asia and the Middle East was disrupted.

clusters.title: UK police arrest almost 900 protesters at pro-Palestine Action rally
clusters.neutral_headline: Nearly 900 Arrested at Pro-Palestine Action Protest in London

items.title: UK police arrest almost 900 protesters at pro-Palestine Action rally
items.standfirst: Organisers say detained demonstrators include 'vicars and priests, war veterans and descendants of Holocaust survivors'.
items.content: Organisers say detained demonstrators include 'vicars and priests, war veterans and descendants of Holocaust survivors'.

items.title: Almost 900 people arrested at Palestine Action ban protest, say Met police
items.standfirst: Demonstration in central London on Saturday led to 857 arrests under Terrorism ActA total of 890 arrests were made at a demonstration in central London on Saturday against the banning of the protest group Palestine Action.Police arrested 857 people under the Terrorism Act for showing support for a proscribed group, while 33 people were arrested for other offences, including 17 for assaults on police officers, the Metropolitan police said. Continue reading...
items.content: Demonstration in central London on Saturday led to 857 arrests under Terrorism ActA total of 890 arrests were made at a demonstration in central London on Saturday against the banning of the protest group Palestine Action.Police arrested 857 people under the Terrorism Act for showing support for a proscribed group, while 33 people were arrested for other offences, including 17 for assaults on police officers, the Metropolitan police said. Continue reading...

items.title: Arrests at rally against Palestine Action ban rise to 890
items.standfirst: The majority of the arrests were for supporting a proscribed group, police say.
items.content: The majority of the arrests were for supporting a proscribed group, police say.

items.title: Almost 900 arrested in London for supporting banned group Palestine Action
items.standfirst: Nearly 900 people were detained by police in London on Saturday for protesting against the ban on Palestine Action, a group the UK government has branded a terrorist organisation. Protesters say the ban is an unwarranted curb on free speech and the right to protest.
items.content: Nearly 900 people were detained by police in London on Saturday for protesting against the ban on Palestine Action, a group the UK government has branded a terrorist organisation. Protesters say the ban is an unwarranted curb on free speech and the right to protest.

clusters.title: New business secretary Peter Kyle going to China for trade talks this week
clusters.neutral_headline: New UK Business Secretary to Visit China for Trade Talks

items.title: New business secretary Peter Kyle going to China for trade talks this week
items.standfirst: Former science secretary promoted in reshuffle to continue UK efforts to revitalise trade relationship with Beijing The UK’s new business secretary, Peter Kyle, will fly to Beijing this week as part of Keir Starmer’s continuing efforts to revitalise the UK’s trade relationship with China and provide growth to the British economy.The former science and technology secretary, who was promoted in Friday’s government reshuffle, is expected to land in China on Wednesday, picking up the schedule of his predecessor, Jonathan Reynolds, who is now the chief whip. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Republican condemns Vance for ‘despicable’ comments on Venezuelan boat strike
clusters.neutral_headline: Senator Condemns Vance for Comments on Venezuelan Boat Strike

items.title: Republican condemns Vance for ‘despicable’ comments on Venezuelan boat strike
items.standfirst: Rand Paul decries ‘thoughtless’ comment after vice-president defends strike against alleged drug traffickersThe Republican senator who heads the homeland security committee has criticized JD Vance for “despicable” comments apparently in support of extrajudicial military killings.“Killing cartel members who poison our fellow citizens is the highest and best use of our military,” the vice-president said in an X post on Saturday, in defense of Tuesday’s US military strike against a Venezuelan boat in the Caribbean Sea, which killed 11 people the administration alleged were drug traffickers. Continue reading...
items.content: Rand Paul decries ‘thoughtless’ comment after vice-president defends strike against alleged drug traffickersThe Republican senator who heads the homeland security committee has criticized JD Vance for “despicable” comments apparently in support of extrajudicial military killings.“Killing cartel members who poison our fellow citizens is the highest and best use of our military,” the vice-president said in an X post on Saturday, in defense of Tuesday’s US military strike against a Venezuelan boat in the Caribbean Sea, which killed 11 people the administration alleged were drug traffickers. Continue reading...

items.title: "Despicable and thoughtless": Vance's drug vessel strike praise slammed by senator

Rand Paul (R-Ky.) blasted Vice President JD Vance Saturday for describing the deadly U.S. strike on a drug vessel as "highest and best use of our military," slamming his sentiment as "despicable and thoughtless." The big picture: Trump administration officials have signaled the attack on an…

items.title: US pilot and influencer released from Chilean air base in Antarctica
items.standfirst: Ethan Guo, 20, had been detained since June after being accused of landing his Cessna illegally in Chilean territory in the Antarctic.
items.content: Ethan Guo, 20, had been detained since June after being accused of landing his Cessna illegally in Chilean territory in the Antarctic.

items.title: American influencer released from Chilean Antarctic air base after 2 months
items.standfirst: American influencer and pilot Ethan Guo has been released to mainland Chile after being stuck at an Antarctic air base for two months. The 20-year-old was attempting to become the youngest person to fly solo to all seven continents when Chilean authorities accused him of landing illegally on their Antarctic territory.
items.content: American influencer and pilot Ethan Guo has been released to mainland Chile after being stuck at an Antarctic air base for two months. The 20-year-old was attempting to become the youngest person to fly solo to all seven continents when Chilean authorities accused him of landing illegally on their Antarctic territory.

ai_summary: Ethan Guo, a US pilot and influencer, was released from an Antarctic air base.
He had been detained since June after landing illegally.
He was attempting to fly solo to all seven continents.
Chilean authorities accused him of landing on their territory.
He was stuck at the air base for two months.
